subdebateinfo.title: Members of Parliament: Taxation of Electorate Allowances (Question No. 1246)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 February 1979:

item.para: 1 ) Did an article in the Sunday Sun, 4 February 1979, report that Queensland State Members of Parliament are having their electorate allowances taxed; if so: (a) are these allowances being taxed; and (b) are the electorate allowances of Members of other Parliaments being taxed or about to be taxed.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

item.para: 1 ) Such an article did appear. As to the remainder of the question the position is:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Electorate allowances are assessable income and are taxed as such. Expenses incurred by a Member of Parliament in representing his or her electorate are allowable deductions except to the extent to which they are of a capital, private or domestic nature. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that because of this compensating factor it has been a general administrative practice not to subject the allowances to tax instalment deductions under the PAYE provisions of the income tax law. Recently the Commissioner decided that this general practice should be reviewed in relation to allowances of the Members referred to by the Senator, but the situation of individual Members is a matter between them and the Commissioner which is protected by the secrecy provisions of the income tax law.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The question of appropriate taxation arrangements in respect of these allowances is kept under constant review by the Commissioner and he has advised that if he has reason to modify present arrangements in any respect he will advise the Members concerned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 February 1979:

quote.para: What statistical projects have been deferred or abandoned by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1977-78 and 1 978-79, and for what reasons.

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: In 1977-78 and 1978-79 it was necessary to review the ABS work program to contain it within its allocated staff and financial resources.
Work on the development of a Wholesale Trade Census in respect of 1 977-78 was discontinued during 1977-78.

During 1 978-79 it was necessary to make further program cuts. To minimise the impact on statistical users, these cuts were made in statistical projects which: were not considered to be mainstream economic and social indicators: were as self-contained as possible so as not to have major repercussions on interrelated projects; and were of such a scale so as not to concentrate the whole impact on one sector of the economy.
As a result, the following collections were discontinued:

item.label: (i)
item.para: Household Income and Expenditure Surveydevelopment work for a 1979-80 survey abandoned;

item.label: (ii)
item.para: Quarterly and Annual Job Vacancy Surveysabandoned during 1978-79;

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Foreign Participation studies- further studies abandoned; and

item.label: (iv)
item.para: Agricultural Finance Surveys in respect of the years 1978-79 and 1979-80.

quote.para: The Government recently approved the re-introduction of the quarterly survey of job vacancies from May 1 979.

subdebateinfo.title: Air and Rail Services: Fuel Consumption (Question No. 1517)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 April 1979:

item.para: 1 ) How much fuel is normally consumed by a Boeing 727 (200 series) in flying non-stop from:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Perth to Sydney;

item.label: (b)
item.para: Sydney to Perth

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) In flying non-stop, a Boeing 727 (200 series) would normally consume

item.label: (a)
item.para: approximately 18,150 kg(40,000 lbs)of aviation turbine fuel between Perth and Sydney

item.label: (b)

talk.start.para: -On 6 March 1979 (Hansard, page 493) Senator O 'Byrne asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning deposits insurance for permanent building societies. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Government has been considering the matter of deposits insurance for permanent building societies following the submission of a report by a working party of Commonwealth officials established to investigate the matter.
Submissions have been received from groups representing building societies and other sectors of the finance industry and discussions held with those groups, as well as with the States.

The issues are complex and their resolution could have important implications for relevant sectors of the finance industry and for Commonwealth/State responsibilities in this area. Accordingly, Ministers have decided to seek more detailed examination of certain issues.

As part of this process, the Prime Minister and the then Acting Treasurer discussed this topic recently with building society representatives and I have myself had a further discussion with them in recent days. The Government will be moving to finalise the matter as quickly as possible.

talk.start.para: -On 4 April 1979 Senator Cavanagh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the following question without notice:

quote.para: Was the practice until 1 November last year to pay totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners a meal allowance when they attended the Daws Road Hospital to see a doctor in the morning and another one in the afternoon? Was that practice terminated in November of last year? Is the meal allowance now paid to TPI pensioners attending the hospital only when they have to wait a period of more than 13 hours to visit a doctor? Is that meal allowance 70c?

answer.para: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: Persons required to travel in connection with Repatriation treatment can qualify for reimbursement of fares and payment of subsistence allowance for accommodation and meals.
Where an overnight stay away from home is not necessary, a meal allowance may be paid in respect of meals partaken while travelling or attending for treatment.

The Government decided in the 1978 Budget that, as from 1 November 1978, subsistence allowance would be payable on the same basis as the allowance payable to Public Service personnel. Therefore, a meal allowance is only payable where a person is absent from home overnight. Or where absences exceed 13 hours or involve travel before 7 a.m. or after 7 p.m.
